greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Self-inverse permutation of natural numbers: 1 is fixed, followed by infinite number of adjacent transpositions (n n+1).
comment: Also, a lexicographically minimal sequence of distinct positive integers such that a(n) is coprime to n. - _Ivan Neretin_, Apr 18 2015

The larger term of the pair [a(n), a(n+1)] is always odd. Had we started the sequence with a(1) = 0, it would be the lexicographically first sequence with this property if always extented with the smallest integer not yet present. - _Eric Angelini_, Feb 17 2017
This sequence is self-inverse. Except for the fixed point 1, it consists completely of 2-cycles: (2n, 2n+1), n > 0.

With a(0)=0, and the rest of the sequence appended, a(n) is the smallest positive number not yet in the sequence such that the arithmetic mean of the first n+1 terms a(0), a(1), ..., a(n) is not an integer; i.e., the sequence is 0, 1, 3, 2, 5, 4, 7, 6, 9, 8, ...
Example: for n=5, (0 + 1 + 3 + 2 + 5)/5 is not an integer.
Fixed points are odd numbers >= 3 and also a(n) = n-2 for even n >= 4. (End)
link: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
F. M. Dekking, Permutations of N generated by left-right filling algorithms, arXiv:2001.08915 [math.CO], 2020.
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (1,1,-1).
formula: a(1) = 1, for n > 0 a(2*n) = 2*a(a(n)) + 1, a(2*n + 1) = 2*a(a(n)). - _Yosu Yurramendi_, Dec 12 2020
mathematica: f[n_] := Rest@ Flatten@ Transpose[{Range[1, n + 1, 2], {1}~Join~Range[2, n, 2]}]; f@ 72 (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 18 2015 *)
Rest@ CoefficientList[Series[x (x^3 - 2 x^2 + 2 x + 1)/((x - 1)^2*(x + 1)), {x, 0, 72}], x] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Feb 17 2017 *)
program: (PARI) { for (n=1, 1000, if (n>1, a=n + (-1)^n, a=1); write("b065190.txt", n, " ", a) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Oct 13 2009
(Python) def a(n): return 1 if n<2 else n + (-1)**n # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 22 2017
a <- c(1,3,2) # If it were c(1,2,3), it would be A000027
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 19 2001
